eccoLocation.resp: This file prepared by Joe Renfro

sourceDesc.p: Search terms extracted from the following text(s):

bibl.author: Alexander, William (d. 1783)
bibl.title: The history of women, from the earliest antiquity, to the present time; giving Some Account of almost every interesting Particular concerning that Sex, among all Nations, ancient and modern. The third edition, with many alterations and corrections. By William Alexander, M.D. In two volumes. ...
bibl.publisher: London : printed for C. Dilly, in the Poultry; and R. Christopher, Stockton, MDCCLXXXII. [1782].
bibl.note: On the previous page it states that there are religious dancers and then other dancers called Balliaderes, "who, in the manner of our strolling players, go about for the amusement of the public; and may be seen for a trifle at their common exhibitions, or will perform in private to any one who will pay what they demand." They have an old man following them who uses an in strument called a Tom. It's almost as though they are their cultures' form of strippers.

bibl.author: Jones, Jenkin, Captain
bibl.title: Hobby horses, a poetic allegory, in five parts. By Jenkin Jones.
bibl.publisher: London : printed for M. Allen, No. 15, Paternoster-Row, [1798].
bibl.note: This selection validates my past note about what these dancers were like and that they were practically strippers. "These female dancers pay very little regard to modesty even in public."
